text:
- Let's bring in
now Jack Barsky.
He was a KGB agent.

He was spying on
the US for a time

during close to the
end of the Cold War.

And that was until he
was caught by the FBI.

Now he is an American
citizen and he is telling
his story in a new book.

It's called "Deep
Undercover, My Secret Life

and Tangled Allegiances
as a KGB Spy in America."

So you can imagine, this
is going to be a pretty
interesting perspective.

Jack, good to have
you here this morning.

Thank you very much
for joining us.

You became a spy, of
course, for the Kremlin.

You were working undercover
here in the United States.

You're hearing all
the allegations

that are now being
made about the election

and how Russia may have
tried to influence it.

Do you think it is possible
that Russia has actually somehow
infiltrated the White House?
[chuckling]

JACK BARSKY: I don't
want to speculate.

Anything is possible in
the intelligence realm.

The bottom line, is when it
comes to intelligence matters,

the real truth, if
it ever comes out,

may take 30, 40, 50
years to come out.

Like for instance what
happened in the United States

with regard to Soviet
spying in the '40s and '50s

is now pretty much out in the
open, but it took a long time.

So today we will not be able
to really find the truth.

- All right, so if we can't
say verify it or prove it right

now, is it something,
and you would know,

is it something that
Russia would want to do
and has tried in the past?

JACK BARSKY: It absolutely is,
but it's exceedingly difficult.

You know, the Manchurian
Candidate, that's fiction.
Let's face it.

It would require a grand
conspiracy, which is nearly
impossible to keep secret.

When I was undercover,
there were about five
people who knew about me, five.
And we kept it pretty secret.

- Well, so if they can't
have a grand conspiracy,
there could be subtle ways.

And what I bring up here is, of
course, we know that there have

been connections
to various people

that are connected to the
President of the United States,
now.

In fact, we're going to
show you a flowchart I

believe that gives you a pretty
good idea of who is connected
and how.

And what I'm wondering,
as you look at this,

and you look at all the various
names that are being thrown out

here, does that imply some
kind of subtle intrigue

either by buying or connecting
to these various members

of the White House and
the administration,
of getting in there?

JACK BARSKY: I honestly
don't buy into the intrigue.

What I would buy
into in a big way,

is the Russians trying to
create chaos in this country,

trying to destabilize
this country.

And in that matter, they
pretty much succeeded.

Because what we are
doing now, we're
throwing bombs at each other.

The book of Mark,
2000 years old,

a house divided against itself
will not stand, famously
quoted by Abraham Lincoln.

And we are right now very
busy dividing our own house.

And if I'm Putin I'm sitting
back and I'm enjoying the show.
I think that is quite likely.

And it also has, you know,
it has historic precedent.

The other stuff to me, I
don't want to speculate.

- So all these
sort of, you know,

paid relationships
or occasions where

members of the administration
have been over in Russia

or they've been paid for this
or that, that you don't think

is an attempt to sort of
buy a mole or buy somebody?

It's more of just
trying to raise

the questions in everyone's mind
and plant these seeds of hmm.
JACK BARSKY: Yes.

And there's probably
some naivete in play,

particularly with
our president, who

was never really in the realm
of international politics.

And there's things that
can happen that way.

But I just cannot,
at this point,

it would be improper
for me to go down
that path to speculate anymore.

- Besides dividing the house,
is there an ulterior motive
here by Putin?

In other words, there
is another grand plan
yet to come and be unveiled.

JACK BARSKY: Well, I think
it's not a secret that Putin

and the Russians are trying
to rebuild what they lost,

what they fought a long
time, never had, and sort of

had for a while
under Stalin, which
is the Soviet/Russian empire.

And as long as we're focused
on each other and internally

and not focused
on that plan, that

gives them more
leeway to do things
that we really don't want done.

- Can you give me an idea of
just the tactics that would be

employed say today by Russian
agents who I presume are here

to cause this destabilization
and questioning
in the media and elsewhere?
JACK BARSKY: Oh, sure.

Find friendly folks in the media
or people who are influencers
and feed them disinformation.

That's been done historically
as long as the KGB existed.
And we now call it fake news.

You know, it's called
disinformation.

- So the wiretap
information, do you think

that could have been
somebody purposely feeding
some journalist or someone?

JACK BARSKY: Whose
wiretap information?

- About Donald Trump
and Trump Tower.
JACK BARSKY: Possible, possible.

Again, you know, I don't want to
join the chorus of speculators.

In the realm of
intelligence, there's
very few people who know.

And the more you start
speculating about things,

the more you're actually feeding
into the folks that are trying
to create that kind of chaos.

- But you do have this obviously
really interesting perspective.

And you must watch
these events, either how

they unfold in the media or how
they are unfolding in the White

House and wonder or think, I
see some fingerprints here,
and they go back to Moscow.
JACK BARSKY: Uh, I see--

I was not involved in
these kinds of operations.
- Understand.

JACK BARSKY: So I was primarily
into political intelligence.

- It's the mindset, I
guess I'm going for.

JACK BARSKY: The
mindset, absolutely.

If you can, you will
probe everywhere you can

and find ways to make a
little dent here and there,
absolutely, sure.
- OK.

JACK BARSKY: And they
have an army of people who

not only people who
are official employees,

but also, you know,
collaborators and informants,
and that hasn't changed.

- Should we be
worried as a nation,
or just aware and alert?

JACK BARSKY: No, what we
should be worried about really
is cyber warfare.

Cyber warfare is the modern,
this is pretty much called
war 2.0.

- And Russia would be willing
to launch cyber warfare
against the United States?

JACK BARSKY: Not
just Russia, others.

And the potential for
damage is phenomenal.

Equals, possibly exceeds
one or two nuclear bombs.

You could pretty much
incapacitate a whole country
if you hack the right systems.
- And you think--

JACK BARSKY: That is
what I'm worried about.

I have a background in
information technology
besides having been a spy.

And I know a bit
about that stuff,
and this is much more dangerous.

And you know, the
political wrangling

back and forth, I don't like
it, it shouldn't be done,
but that's a fact.

But I think the danger
is really for us

to not focus on the real
issue, which is cyber warfare.

- Do you think we're
being distracted?
JACK BARSKY: Yes, we are.
- Intentionally so?
JACK BARSKY: Yes, we are.
- A frightening thought.

Jack Barsky, thank you
very much for joining us.

JACK BARSKY: You're
most welcome.
- Welcome, thank you.
